questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a first-generation cephalosporin?
questions.explanation: Cefaclor is not a first-generation cephalosporin. It is a second-generation oral cephalosporin. First-generation cephalosporins are : • Oral formulation • Cefadroxil • Cephalexin • Cephradine • Parenteral formulation - cefazolin

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient is undergoing orthopedic surgery. Which of the following first-generation 
cephalosporins can you use for surgical prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
The first-generation cephalosporin indicated for surgical prophylaxis is Cefazolin. It is the 
preferred agent for surgical prophylaxis when skin flora is the likely pathogen. Cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cephradine are first-generation oral cephalosporins.

questions.question:
Question 3: You want to prescribe an oral second-generation cephalosporin to a patient with pneumonia. 
Which of the following drugs will you choose?
questions.explanation: Cefaclor is a second-generation oral cephalosporin. Option A: Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Options B and D: Cefadroxil and Cephradine are oral first-generation cephalosporins.

questions.question:
Question 4: In comparison with first-generation cephalosporins, second-generation cephalosporins have 
which of the following properties?

options.a: Greater activity against gram positive bacteria
options.b: Lesser activity against gram positive bacteria

questions.explanation:
Second-generation cephalosporins have lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria when 
compared with first-generation cephalosporins. Properties of second-generation cephalosporins, when compared to first-generation 
cephalosporins, are: • Lesser activity against gram-positive bacteria • Broader gram-negative activity against Hemophilus species, indole-positive Proteus, and 
Klebsiella species • Anaerobes like B.fragilis are susceptible to second-generation cephalosporins like cefoxitin and 
cefotetan but not first-generation cephalosporins

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is a third-generation cephalosporin that can be given orally?
questions.explanation:
508 
Sold by @itachibot Cefixime is a third-generation oral cephalosporin.

questions.question: Question 6: Cephalosporins are not useful in which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Ampicillin is the drug of choice for listeriosis, which is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, and 
cephalosporins are not useful in treating this condition. Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, which is considered as a treatment of choice for 
gonorrhea and severe forms of Lyme disease. Cefoperazone and ceftazidime are third-generation cephalosporins that have clinically significant 
activity against Pseudomonas. Cephalosporins

questions.question:
Question 7: The pus culture and sensitivity report of a hospitalized patient with diabetic ulcer is positive 
for pseudomonas. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The drug that can be used in this patient is Ceftazidime, which is a third-generation parenteral 
cephalosporin having significant anti-pseudomonal action. Cefpodoxime proxetil is a third-generation oral cephalosporin. It does not have significant 
antipseudomonal action. Cephradine and cefotetan are first and second-generation cephalosporins with no 
antipseudomonal action. Antipseudomonal cell wall synthesis inhibitors are: • Cephalosporins: • Third generation - Ceftazidime, Cefoperazone • Fourth generation - Cefepime and cefpirome. They are also used against enterobacter • Fifth generation - Ceftolozane 509 
Sold by @itachibot • Extended-spectrum penicillins: • Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin • Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements about cefepime is false?

options.b: Dose should be reduced in renal failure

questions.explanation:
Cefepime, which is a fourth-generation cephalosporin, has good activity against 
Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and S. aureus, but not against MRSA. It is effective in serious 
infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia, septicemia and febrile neutropenia. Cefepime is excreted primarily through kidneys and dose reduction is necessary for renal 
failure. Encephalopathy and non-convulsive status epilepticus have been reported with the use of 
cefepime.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 34-year-old man presents with a discharging wound post-operatively. Cultures reveal 
infection with MRSA. Which of the following cephalosporins can be used for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ceftaroline is the cephalosporin that is indicated for MRSA infections and hence can be used in 
this patient. It is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin and along with ceftobiprole is grouped 
as fifth-generation cephalosporins. Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effective 
against MRSA and penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae. Cefepime and cefpirome are fourth-generation cephalosporins with no significant action on 
MRSA. Ceftolozane is a fifth-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin with no action on MRSA.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterday 
at the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the following 
cephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does not 
require dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone. All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need a 
dose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominant 
biliary excretion. Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepatic 
impairment.

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the drug of choice for a patient who presents with an initial episode of Clostridium 
difficile infection?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is 
fidaxomicin. It is a macrocyclic antibiotic. 510 
Sold by @itachibot Fidaxomicin is preferred because of its safety profile and higher beneficial effects. But in 
resource-limited settings where it is not available, vancomycin can be used for the treatment of 
this condition. Treatment of Clostridium difficile infection: • Fidaxomicin • Vancomycin • Metronidazole Vancomycin and fidaxomicin are more effective than metronidazole. All of the above drugs are 
given orally. Loracarbef is a second-generation cephalosporin and is not indicated in pseudomembranous 
colitis caused by Clostridium difficile. NOTE: As per the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) management guidelines 2021, 
Fidaxomicin is now preferred over Vancomycin for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium 
difficile infection. Vancomycin can be used as an alternative drug.

questions.question:
Question 12: 504 
Sold by @itachibot What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of vancomycin is cell wall synthesis inhibition. The bacterial cell wall has long chains of peptidoglycan and is cross-linked to each other by the 
action of the enzyme transglycosylase. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide group of antibiotics that 
binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of the synthesized peptidoglycan. This inhibits the 
transglycosylase enzyme and prevents elongation and cross-linking of peptidoglycan. This leads to 
the weakening of the cell wall causing lysis. It exhibits a time-dependant or concentration-independent killing of bacteria. It primarily acts on 
Gram +ve organisms which are resistant to other antibiotics such as methicillin-resistant 
staphylococcus and ampicillin resistant enterococci. Lipoglycopeptides are a new generation of glycopeptide congeners which include telavancin, 
dalbavancin, and oritavancin. Dalbavancin and Oritovancin are administered as a single 
intravenous dose for skin and soft-tissue infections. 511 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of :
questions.explanation:
Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea and 
staphylococcal enterocolitis. Its oral formulation is not absorbed systemically and hence is used for local action in the 
gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient on intravenous vancomycin develops flushing and erythematous lesions. On 
examination, tachycardia, and hypotension are noted. By what mechanism does vancomycin 
cause these effects?

options.b: Direct toxic effect on mast cells

questions.explanation:
The given scenario depicts red man syndrome associated with vancomycin. It occurs due to a 
direct toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine. Red man or red neck syndrome is a non-allergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion of 
vancomycin characterized by: • Flushing • Erythematous, urticarial reactions • Tachycardia • Hypotension Slow infusion, prophylactic use of antihistamines can reduce the incidence.

questions.question: Question 15: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice for each.
questions.explanation:
Vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It 
should be used only if the organism is resistant to other drugs. 512 
Sold by @itachibot Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides. Metronidazole is used in the treatment of the following conditions: • Giardiasis • Trichomoniasis • Amoebiasis • Bacterial vaginosis • Pseudomembranous colitis Meropenem is used in infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria like Klebsiella. Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL (extended-spectrum beta-lactamases). Therefore, 
carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem and ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by ESBLs. 
They are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria, 
like Klebsiella and E. coli. Penicillins like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

questions.question:
Question 16: 505 
Sold by @itachibot A patient allergic to penicillin requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following can you 
safely prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Aztreonam can be safely given to a patient with a history of allergy to penicillin. It is a 
monobactam group of -Lactam antibiotics resistant to narrow-spectrum beta-lactamase 
produced by bacteria. It lacks cross-sensitivity with the other beta-lactams, except for ceftazidime. It has activity only 
against gram-negative bacteria. It has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following carbapenems has increased risk of causing seizures?
questions.explanation:
Imipenem is the carbapenem that is associated with an increased risk of causing seizures, 
especially when high doses are given to patients with CNS lesions. Excretion of imipenem is mainly renal and dosage modification is required to avoid seizures in 
renal failure patients.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false about extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?

options.a: They can hydrolyse penicillins, cephalosporins as well as monobactam
options.c: Ambler classification of ESBL is based on amino acid sequence
options.d: Third and fourth generation cephalosporins are used for detection of ESBL

questions.explanation:
Carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by 
extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and hence are indicated in the treatment of infections 
caused by ESBL producing bacteria. Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by bacteria that are able to hydrolyze antibiotics and make 
them ineffective, thus making the bacteria resistant to these antibiotics. They confer resistance 
against: 513 
Sold by @itachibot • Penicillins • Cephalosporins • Monobactams Beta lactamases hydrolyze first and second-generation cephalosporins but are ineffective against 
third and fourth-generation. Beta lactamases are classified into four categories based on their amino acid sequences, by the 
Ambler classification. ESBLs also hydrolyze third and fourth-generation cephalosporins - cefotaxime, ceftazidime, 
ceftriaxone and cefepime.

questions.question: Question 19: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem. Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase. It is administered with 
cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the 
action of imipenem. Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not 
necessary with meropenem.

questions.question:
Question 20: 506 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with a complicated urinary tract infection is put on a newly approved combination 
of meropenem and a non-suicidal beta-lactamase inhibitor. Identify this drug.
questions.explanation:
Vaborbactam is a recently approved non-suicidal beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is indicated in 
combination with meropenem for complicated urinary tract infections. Sulbactam, tazobactam and clavulanic acid are suicidal inhibitors of beta-lactamase enzyme. Suicidal inhibitors are irreversible inhibitors that can permanently inactivate the -lactamase 
through secondary chemical reactions in the enzyme active site. 514 
Sold by @itachibot Miscellaneous Antimicrobials
